quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 13 Quiz 3
quiz.subtitle: 13.3: Nuclear Equations
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Conservation of mass number and atomic number in nuclear reactions

questions.question: In a balanced nuclear equation, which two quantities must be conserved?
options: Sum of mass numbers and sum of atomic numbers
Total number of molecules and total moles
Sum of oxidation states and total volume
Total mass in grams and number of electrons
questions.explanation: The total mass number (A) and total atomic number (Z) must be identical on both the reactant and product sides.

questions.question: Which particle is required to balance the following equation: $^{9}_{4}Be + ^{4}_{2}He \rightarrow ^{12}_{6}C + ?$
questions.explanation: Mass: $9 + 4 = 13$; Product side has 12, so 1 is missing. Atomic: $4 + 2 = 6$; Product side has 6, so 0 is missing. $^{1}_{0}n$ (a neutron) balances it.

questions.question: Identify the missing product: $^{210}_{84}Po \rightarrow ^{206}_{82}Pb + ?$
questions.explanation: The mass number decreases by 4 and the atomic number by 2, which corresponds to an alpha particle ($^{4}_{2}He$).

questions.question: In the reaction $^{14}_{7}N + ^{4}_{2}He \rightarrow ^{17}_{8}O + ?$, the missing particle is:
questions.explanation: Total mass: $14+4=18$ (Product: $17+1=18$). Total atomic: $7+2=9$ (Product: $8+1=9$). $^{1}_{1}p$ or $^{1}_{1}H$ is a proton.

questions.question: Which symbol represents a positron in a nuclear equation?
questions.explanation: A positron has negligible mass and a $+1$ charge, denoted as $^{0}_{+1}e$ or $^{0}_{+1}\beta$.

questions.question: Balance the decay of Carbon-14: $^{14}_{6}C \rightarrow ^{14}_{7}N + ?$
questions.explanation: The mass stays the same, and the atomic number increases by 1 ($6 \rightarrow 7 + -1$). This is beta-minus decay.

questions.question: In electron capture, the electron is written as a:
questions.explanation: In electron capture, an inner-shell electron is 'captured' by the nucleus, so it appears on the left side of the equation.

questions.question: Which particle balances $^{27}_{13}Al + ^{4}_{2}He \rightarrow ^{30}_{15}P + ?$
questions.explanation: Mass: $27+4=31$ ($30+1=31$). Atomic: $13+2=15$ ($15+0=15$). The missing particle is a neutron.

questions.question: What is the product of the positron emission of $^{11}_{6}C$?
questions.explanation: Positron emission ($^{0}_{+1}e$) decreases the atomic number by 1: $^{11}_{6}C \rightarrow ^{11}_{5}B + ^{0}_{+1}e$.

questions.question: The notation $^{0}_{0}\gamma$ indicates that gamma radiation:
options: Does not change the mass or atomic number of the isotope.
Converts a proton into a neutron.
Is a reactant in all fusion reactions.
questions.explanation: Gamma rays are high-energy photons; they have no mass or charge and only represent a loss of energy from the nucleus.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent. You can balance any nuclear transformation.
scoreMessages.70: Good. Remember that mass and charge must balance on both sides.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Watch the difference between reactants and products.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on summing the top and bottom numbers across the arrow.
